petitioner.name: KELLOGG BROWN & ROOT SERVICES, INC., ET AL.

respondent.name: UNITED STATES, EX REL. BENJAMIN CARTER.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 12-1497, Kellogg Brown & Root Services v. United States, Ex Rel. Benjamin Carter. Mr. Elwood.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is it unusual that a criminal statute of limitations would be much longer than a civil statute of limitations, which is the effect of your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Didn't some states used to have no statute for -- for murder, and yet had a statute of limitations on wrongful death claims?  I think that's -- that's the case, with respect to state law, anyway. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Were you adopting the argument of the New England Foundation, the amici brief?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Elwood, I take the point, and that seems like a fair understanding of why that term came out.  But it wasn't the only change that they made at that point.  And taking that term out may have had more than one reason, of course. So two other changes they make are, they put in the word "any."  So the old statute just says "offense" and now it's "any offense," which suggests breadth and expansiveness.  And the other thing, of course, is that they do all of this in connection with this Contract Settlement Act, which presumably refers both to civil and to criminal matters.  And it follows right after this Contract Settlement Act and suggests Alderson Reporting Company that it's following on it. So, you know, put all those three things together:  The taking out of the indictment language, the putting in the word "any," and the passage in conjunction with the Contract Settlement Act.  I think that that would be an argument on the other side.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Contract settlement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Contract settlement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And that goes for the government as -- I mean, suppose the government, not a relator, brings a False Claims case against a contractor.  The government wouldn't get the -- the -- under your view, the government doesn't get the suspension?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And we in any way --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Assuming we agree with you on the first question --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- should we -- should we get to the second?  And how would we if we believe -- if you were right on the first?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The only problem -- the problem you have with this argument -- and it's -- has substantial force to it -- but you give no significance of the word "pending."  You almost write that out of the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How about "former"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: "Pending" is a very strange word to pick.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Or "said action" or "that action."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, aren't you going to -- besides the problem that you're -- you're talking , yourâ€™re not giving "pending" any meaning, you're also destroying the force of an original source.  I mean, the -- the public disclosure bar doesn't apply to an original source.  And you're sort of blocking original sources from bringing suits, when a prior case involved a dismissal for a technicality, or a dismissal because this was in the public domain.  But that's not true for an original source.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, the reality is you don't need the qui tam unless the government doesn't want to waste resources on something, but that doesn't mean that they didn't find that there might be something there. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But it may not want to prosecute it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You have to assume that what the intent is, is not to force the government to prosecute but to get recovery, for -- for the government.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you have any idea how collateral estoppel works in this area?  I actually don't know.  But let's assume that you -- that you're, that the adversary won a claim against you.  Could someone else come in and you've now won for the government, essentially, could anyone else file a suit or would they be stopped because --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Exactly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The relator is treated as the government for preclusion purposes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And that was at least, at least sole judge after verdict.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, there is -- there is good authority, at least in the court of appeals, for that position.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But is it your -- your -- is it your position suit number 1 is filed, it's dismissed within weeks without prejudice,  no other relator can file?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The question is whether somebody else could come in.  So you have somebody who is the first filer and comes in with a sloppy complaint and it's not stated with sufficient specificity; dismissed.  And that person goes  away.  You're saying nobody else can ever come in.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What if it was a perfect -- a perfect complaint, but he sued in the wrong court, or there was no personal jurisdiction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Dismissed without juris- -- dismissed without prejudice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No.  My hypothetical is dismissed without prejudice, but it's a beautifully drawn complaint.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's dismissed for failure to prosecute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: For nonmerits ground, and so nobody else can come in?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that first file rule was meant to protect the first filer in that -- well, one aspect of it is the first filer doesn't have to worry about a race to judgment.  Somebody else files second and gets the judgment first. So I thought that that was -- one of the chief things was to protect the first filer and also to protect that filer's recovery so he doesn't have to split up whatever the qui tam plaintiff gets.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The first filer is a race to the courthouse.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we know in this case -- there were three suits.  Thorpe, I think, was the first.  Do we know why those suits dropped out?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The first Carter, the first Carter suit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The first Thorpe.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And you say that kills it for every -- anybody else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Were any of them filed by original sources?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Were any of them filed by original sources?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But it's -- it's not a pending action later.  I mean, when that action's been dismissed or been completed, you say that a later action is prohibited even though there is no pending action, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Since you're getting into that event, I mean, to me, it makes perfect sense to apply it just to the pending action.  The action goes away. Number 2 person -- and that means there isn't going to be the problem that Justice Ginsburg suggested, so we don't have that problem.  And now we have a new person who can bring a suit if and only if he is the original source.  Well, if he's the original source, let him recover.  Why not?  And your answer to that is, well, he didn't tell the government all this stuff, the first guy did. Well, see, but that's not the only purpose of the qui tam action.  It has other purposes.  It's to reward the person who, in fact, did discover this thing and -- and made every effort to bring it to public attention. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know.  But he can't -- but other -- other things prevent him from bringing it unless he's the original source.  Am I not right?  I mean, it's all been disclosed, you know.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Everything's been disclosed by number 1 --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Let's take the mine run --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't want to interrupt. I don't want to interrupt your reserving your time.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Stone.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it's placed -- placed in the Criminal Code.  It's placed in Title 18.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Is there any civil offense in Title 18? one. There in --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's in 18.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that about fraud?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And what does the word "offense" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What does the word "offense" mean in that provision?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In that provision, what -- what does the word --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's a criminal offense, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It wouldn't make any sense in Title 18 unless the offense they're referring to is one -- one of the criminal offenses of Title 18.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Read the provision again, would you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE        ALITO
speakers.text: Yes.  But 1033 is a criminal provision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I think -- I think the point these people are trying to make, perhaps --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- is that that provision you've read provides for a civil action by the attorney general --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- against a person who has committed an offense.  What offense?  An offense elsewhere defined in 18.  Is that offense defined elsewhere criminal or civil?  It is criminal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's the point, I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know you disagree, but -- so let's turn to the other offense it cross-references --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- and why don't you read that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I've got the language of that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I -- I agree with -- the word "offense" appears and it provides for a civil action.  What I wonder is, when you turn to the particular provisions that do that, and look at the word "offense," is that word "offense" in those civil remedy provisions referring to a civil or criminal behavior?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: To civil you say.  So let's read --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the word "offense" Alderson Reporting Company refers to the civil behavior.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  Good.  Read me the example because I must have missed it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Stone, don't take this for more than it's worth because I think there are plenty of arguments against you, but I'm actually not sure I understand this one.  I mean, it seems to me if your view is it applies to both criminal and civil offenses --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- well, Congress had to put the thing someplace.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: It could have put it in the criminal code or it could have put it with all the other civil provisions --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Either way, there'd be kind Alderson Reporting Company of a mismatch.  And presumably, this started out as criminal and it refers largely to criminal, and so that's where it goes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What is your -- what is your --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What is your answer to the argument that this would be a big change if it previously applied only to crimes and then, according to you, it was changed so that it applied to civil claims as well.  That would be a big change.  What is your response to the argument that we might find a little -- a bit of evidence here or there that that's what was intended, but Mr. Elwood says there's nothing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Is that your -- that's your best evidence, that there was a reference to litigation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where -- where did that appear?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.  That's all I needed to know.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What Congress was that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that's -- where does that appear?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Two -- two Senate committees or just one Senate committee?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that's the Congress.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, all that's true except --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- except when you're dealing with an old statute that used to be clearly criminal, and it seems to me  at that point the burden -- when that statute is expanded -- the burden is on you to show that it's been changed from the criminal to the civil --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- to include the civil. Alderson Reporting Company And, you know, that's a different burden from what you expect.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, were they --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Were they district courts? Four district courts?  Is that it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And did Congress know about those?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Ah, ah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Changed the law to do what?  They changed it to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- operating prospectively, not just to crimes that had already occurred?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So that's one change that everybody agrees.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The government can pursue it in a criminal case.  The question is whether --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the civil -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Who urges the word "offense"?  That's the limitation that is urged, which is normally used to connote a crime.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And I don't think that changes --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- if you put the word "any" in front of it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The problem is that --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Justice Ginsburg.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Everyone agrees that from 1921 on, it was understood that this was a criminal statute and I think the point has been made before.  If Congress really was going to change it, to vote it all onto the excision of two words which can be explained on other grounds, it's a bit much.  Wouldn't Congress have said, now we're going to make it -- we want it to be civil, so we're going to make it clear that it's civil?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, there was a reason.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The statute acted retrospectively for the first part of its history, and then they took it out when it was going to operate prospectively.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you can either reserve time or move on.  It's up to you.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What happens -- what happens if you have a first filer who brings a claim, it's successful, either gets a judgment or gets a settlement, and the case is over?  It's no longer pending.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not sure the government will agree with that, as you confidently predict, but I guess we'll ask the government.  But I think --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think you're saying that if somebody brings a suit and is -- and loses, the government is -- is thereby precluded from joining a later suit.  Right?  The government is. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But they didn't intervene.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Then they are bound.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We'll see what the government thinks of that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Stone.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry for my confusion about the time reservation.  Thank you. Mr. Stewart.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is there -- is there a provision that uses the word "offense" even though it may be civil, where that word "offense" in that provision refers to something other than a criminal Alderson Reporting Company offense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Every use of the word "offense" in Title 18 is in reference to a criminal offense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But the answer to my question was yes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, whoa, whoa.  You can Alderson Reporting Company say that it limited it or you can say that it -- it showed -- it showed that the word "offense" in that statute was being used to mean a criminal offense, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It could.  I acknowledge that sometimes you can say "offense" and it means civil, sometimes you can say that it means criminal, and sometimes you can say it means both. But what that language did in the original statute was to make it clear that the word "offense" in this statute was being used in a criminal sense.  And I don't think that that implication is eliminated by simply taking out the -- taking out the "now indictable" language, which could have been eliminated for a very different reason; and that is, to show that it -- it operates prospectively.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But there would be no other Alderson Reporting Company reason for eliminating the word "criminal"; whereas, there is a very good other reason for eliminating the phrase "now indictable."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is the Korean War covered by the WSLA?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is that your -- is that your position now, that only declared wars are covered? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Was there such an authorization in the Korean War?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no.  I mean at the time.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't think there was, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm trying to get at the question of the breadth of your position.  As I -- as I understand it, you're now saying "at war" doesn't necessarily have to have a declared war.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So if -- so if the current version were effect -- were in effect in 1950, the Korean War would not be covered, because there wasn't a declared war?  And my understanding is there wasn't a specific authorization for the use of forces.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Stewart, before your time runs out, what -- what is the Government's position on the -- on the point raised by counsel for Respondent; namely, if there is a dismissal of -- on the merits of a -- a civil action, is the government barred from later bringing a different action on the same claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If the case is not -- the first case is not dismissed on the merits, dismissed without prejudice and then relator 2 files, your position is that that suit may be maintained?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm curious to know, just because of background, would the first suit toll the statute of limitations as to the second relator?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Stewart. Mr. Elwood, you have reserved 4 minutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Relator two is treated as the Government for this purpose.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
